snippet.textDisplay:
I made a long post (comment) on this, a number of years back, when Stephen Hawking was still looking for an answer to the Black Hole Information Paradox for what happens to all the matter and energy that's pulled into the BH.
Back then and today I believed that it wasn't simply a hole but a hugh vortex created by the explosion of a humongous star.
The explosion combined with the powerful vacuum created or opened a hugh vortex into another dimension. This seemed logical at the time and also answered the paradox. I also believed that the named "Hawkins Radiation " was created or effected by the intense heat from all the matter being pulled back in by the BH, being compressed and broken back down into pure electromagnet energy, from which it was originally created, to allow it to pass into another dimension through the vortex.
Hawkins also stated a short time later that He believed that the BH
may be a vortex to another dimension but did not elaborate further on this scenario.
I don't accept that there was an initial, so called, Big Bang that created everything. I think that creation has been going on for eternity throughout the universe or universes and the Black Holes are an integral part of the mechanics of the ongoing infinite creation.
This also answers a bucket load of questions. One is:"The universe being infinate"? Yes and possibly multi-dimensional although we actually believe that our Galaxies are multi-dimensional. All matter was originally created and therefore must have an end. In the universe/s this may take trillions of years but it will happen. I feel that this is another unwritten law.
"FROM DUST TO DUST."

snippet.textDisplay: One glaring problem with this hypothesis.  How do you account then for the infinite regress?  If black holes "IN" a universe, spawn other universes within that black hole, then our universe must be within a black hole of another universe.  This regression would be infinite.  So we are back to the cosmological arguments put forth by Thomas Aquinas.  You cannot have an infinite regress. Something cannot be created from nothing.
snippet.textOriginal: One glaring problem with this hypothesis.  How do you account then for the infinite regress? snippet.textDisplay: I started off disliking this video but then I got it. Asking the hypothetical questions in the hope of finding real answers requires great skill or luck asking the right questions. How do we evaluate how good a question is? An example would be similar to how fake news is used to create straw man fallacies to obfuscate another sides objectives but if there is just too much fake news everyone loses. Similarly if too many people are asking the most obviously "wrong" questions everyone loses because so much time is wasted on the "wrong" questions. I suppose it could boil down to the objective of the person asking the question, are they looking for real answers or are they just wasting time. Hmm it's a tough problem 🤔 It would be tough to appoint blame or criticism on people asking the "wrong" questions without good evidence that it is wrong. Unfortunately there are too many people who would rather appear to be successful than admit fault and move onto a possibly better path. Maybe if people were more educated in matters they disagree with they might think twice before attacking alternatives. Human nature sure throws a spanner in the works!

snippet.textDisplay:
This is somewhat tangential to a thought I come back to a lot. Generally, I'm coming at it from the direction of "what's beyond the event horizon", not at all in terms of the anthropic principle, but I believe I have some interesting context to add.

Have you ever taken a balloon (or something inflatable), made a ring with your finger so that it makes two separate sections, and then pushed the fluid back and forth? For better or for worse, I like to think of black hole collapse like taking all the fluid in one side and suddenly pushing it into the other.

The small hole created by your fingers would be like the event horizon, and the fluid is clearly, um... well energy?, it could already potentially be complicated beyond our capacity to understand! So for simplicity, let's just say energy or mass or whatever you want because after the next step it isn't going to matter :D

Unlike inside the balloon, we don't have any idea what the space is like on the other side of the event horizon. Is it even "space" at all? Could there be more directions of time? Or maybe even dimensions with properties we wouldn't even possibly be able to wrap our heads around? Something is being squeezed into somewhere is the name of my very awesome thesis.

It's really hard to not see some kind of connection between a black hole collapse and a big bang, or universes that expand into nothingness and black holes that radiate away into nothingness. Even though the "expansion" might not be in any form we could recognize and we might not even know exactly what is being transferred, I think the metaphor is a lot more intellectually nourishing than following our current mathematical models into singularities.

As for cosmological evolution, surely there's at least a limiting this process from the whatever being transferred to each new generation (ie smaller black hole, smaller universe, less whatever to make more universes). I would be more inclined to believe in some kind of oscillation between different types of universes as black holes collapse in each rather than something similar to biological evolution. Maybe this would allow for getting around a law of conservation of whatever.

Cosmological evolution may not be true, but I would way rather this theory be the laypersons understanding of black holes than some bullshit about "infinitely dense points".

Btw, I'm stoned af and never got any further in science than a 3 on my AP physics exam almost 15 years ago, just in case you missed the part about my thesis title and take this too seriously.

Or maybe even dimensions with properties we wouldn't even possibly be able to wrap our heads around? Something is being squeezed into somewhere is the name of my very awesome thesis.

It's really hard to not see some kind of connection between a black hole collapse and a big bang, or universes that expand into nothingness and black holes that radiate away into nothingness. Even though the "expansion" might not be in any form we could recognize and we might not even know exactly what is being transferred, I think the metaphor is a lot more intellectually nourishing than following our current mathematical models into singularities.

As for cosmological evolution, surely there's at least a limiting this process from the whatever being transferred to each new generation (ie smaller black hole, smaller universe, less whatever to make more universes). I would be more inclined to believe in some kind of oscillation between different types of universes as black holes collapse in each rather than something similar to biological evolution. Maybe this would allow for getting around a law of conservation of whatever.

Cosmological evolution may not be true, but I would way rather this theory be the laypersons understanding of black holes than some bullshit about "infinitely dense points".

Btw, I'm stoned af and never got any further in science than a 3 on my AP physics exam almost 15 years ago, just in case you missed the part about my thesis title and take this too seriously.

snippet.textDisplay:
A necessary force in natural selection of life is competition. Black holes and their associated universes on the other hand do not compete, they are completely isolated. Favoring black hole creation does not change anything because, given an infinite number of iterations, there is guaranteed to be one suitable for life even if changes in constants are random. And it's not a surprise that we find ourselves in one of those universes.


Also the fixation on carbon-oxygen life seems strange to me given we're discussing crazy things like universes inside black holes with completely different physics from ours. The only requirement for life is the ability to create complex, stable, interacting conglomerates of stuff. It doesn't matter what the stuff actually is. These happened to be organic molecules on Earth but they don't need to be. They can be something different given massive differences in physics and chemistry. They can be something completely different like stable field fluctuations. Who knows, maybe we have field/energy life in our universe but just can't interact with it because we exist on different levels.

snippet.textDisplay:
The thing I don't understand about physics is the apparent assumption that we inhabit a unique universe—that there is a single ‘reality’. If science is the study of the observable, then it is, at any given point in time, finite. If there are any real-valued parameters at all, then we inhabit, up to isomorphism, an infinite class of universes distinguished by our observations, and not by the exact values of those parameters (which, by construction of the real numbers, is not a finite amount of information). Again, if a region of space has finite information capacity—or if our minds have a finite state space—and there are any real-valued parameters (because, for example, space is ℝ³-ish or even ℝ²-ish), we automatically inhabit an infinite class of universes. The only formulation in which there is a unique reality is the one in which the observer has, at least in principle, enough information to determine the entire multiverse, and physics seems confident that this is not our situation.
I actually suspect that the assumption that ℝ has a physical interpretation is incorrect, but I also see no reason to believe in a reality other than what we observe. At best we might invoke Occam and define ‘reality’ as the minimal model of our observations, but (a) that begs a metric and (b) it rather puts paid to these ‘statistical’ arguments—doesn't it?

snippet.textDisplay:
Shame on you for regurgitating the fine tuning argument. The universe is so comfy? Is that we the only place we have ever found life is in a small band around a sat where the temperature is just right in special kinds of systems where the radiation is REALLY low in special kinds of planets where the pressure is just right on special locations where the environment lines up in a stable way and on further special conditions where the chemicals available are just right? That is evidence that something special is going on giving us such a benefit?

And so what if "life as we know it wouldn't exist."? There's no reason to suspect that conditions in such a situation wouldn't be more favorable to life. Maybe if the mass of the electron change there would be an abundance of intelligent brain masses that formed in space when clusters of electrons happened across each other and they would be wondering how they are so lucky that they dominate a massive 8% of the universe. Or maybe there's a universe where life takes up about 100% unlike ours that has about 0%

You are like a rain puddle looking around at the fantastic luck it had being surrounded by a pothole in the road shaped exactly to the form of the water and thinking about how lucky it is to have gravity and pressure at just the right amounts to hold it perfectly inside. There's no good reason to think anything here was made for us.

However if you wanted to buy into this, life might be the best reason. If a universe had super good conditions and those inside knew it, I expect that intelligent life would make new black holes to give others part of the good life. A black hole farming universe might have a symbiotic relationship with intelligent life.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the thing about neutron stars being a little bit heavier than expected falsifies the theory that our universe comes from an evolutionary line of black holes. My understanding of biological evolution is that it will optimize things with extreme precision unless it's compensating for multiple, contradictory selective pressures. For example, evolution won't make all animals as big and muscular as they could possibly be because that would require them to consume more food. So some sort of balance of factors will be achieved. From what I saw here, the only selective pressure on black hole universes should be their birth rate. I would expect neutron stars to have exactly the mass that this theory predicts with no detectable difference.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem with "cosmological natural selection" is that it ultimately favors universes with such strong gravity that all matter within them collapses into black holes, to thus create as many new universes as possible. So I'm afraid I have to call BS on this hypothesis.
snippet.textOriginal: The problem with "cosmological natural selection" is that it ultimately favors universes with such strong gravity that _all_ matter within them collapses into black holes, to thus create as many new universes as possible. So I'm afraid I have to call BS on this hypothesis.

snippet.textDisplay: The biggest issue would be the "Selection". As far as I'm aware there's no method for universes to "compete", and there is nothing to select for. Any possible universe that produces black holes, will likely happen. Just humans can only have around 1 kid at a time, compared to bugs reproducing constantly, therefore outnumbering us vastly, we still persist as a species. Likewise galaxies that produce a small amount of black holes will be just as successful as black hole tuned galaxies. So the only thing this idea really does is constrain the ratio of universe types. Which then makes any solution like neutron star mass essentially reliant on the doomsday argument, if the maximum size is bigger then 2, then all you know is that you're either not in the optimal universe for black hole formation, or due to the anthropic principle you find yourself in a universe with less optimal conditions for black hole formation,(at least from neutron stars) but just optimal enough  to form supermassive blackholes to hold galaxies together, if so then fine tuning is still there. Also, what happens when black holes collide? This whole thing assumes black holes are static, if two black holes collide does that look like two universes colliding? Do they impact each others constants?

snippet.textDisplay: A quick side note: In order for natural selection to occur in a population, individuals have to compete for a limited reservoir of resources. What should that resource be in the case of universes and how would they compete for it? There is no selection pressure for higher reproduction of universes otherwise. You could propose however, that the number of universes being better at proliferating into new ones is higher, thus you would be more likely to find yourself in one of those, but there we hit the anthropic principle again..

What if the cosmological constants are emergent properties of the quantum interactions and they are not set by luck? Instead the constants are only allowed within a range set by the principles of the big bang itself.
Also, even the largest black hole is an infinitely small fraction of the total mass of our own universe. Even if a singularity created a new fabric of space time, there would not be enough material, matter and dark matter, to expand into a new universe.

snippet.textDisplay: One problem. And its a big one. All alleged black hole universes are spacially infinite, are eternal, contain only one mass, are not expanding and either asymptotically flat or curved. However, all alleged big bang universes are either spacially finite in one case or spacially infinite two different cases, are of finite age (13.8 billion years), contain radiation and many masses, and are not asymptotically anything. Thus, by their very definition big bang universes and black hole universes are mutually exclusive. They cannot co-exist.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm gonna give my own input and opinion on black holes themselves here, since it seems like a good opportunity. None of this is even backed up by anything, it's just to pick peoples' brains.

What I think a black hole is:

1: Black holes aren't created through supernova's. When a star massive enough begins fusing iron, more and more heavy elements
are created and the core gets gradually denser under the extreme increases in mass density from above it. This process
continues and here is where the difference between the creation of a neutron star and a black hole is determined.
Matter at the very microscopic gravitational center of the star is crushed densely enough to form neutrons. When those
neutrons undertake enough gravitational force that pushes them beyond their limits to withstand, an extremely small,
microscopic, perhaps even quantum scale black hole is created. This is the bell that announces the star's doom.
The black hole begins eating the core, the outer core and the rest of the star from the inside out; gaining mass as it does so.
With the increase in mass, the black hole grows in volume as well, or at least its event horizon grows. Slowly but surely,
the black hole consumes the entire star from the inside like a parasite born out of its own heart. Now, it's possible that
at some point, the star's outer layers can no longer support being in a spherical shape as the black hole spins and
collapses into an accretion disk. This event can be seen as a sort of supernova, but it doesn't have to happen that way.
The main point is just that the creation of the black hole happens before the supernova happens.
If there is enough matter left for the black hole to feast on, it can create a quasar so signal its birth.
Thus a black hole as we know them is formed.

2. What it is now, is anyone's guess, but I like looking at it like this: The event horizon of a black hole is like an atmosphere.
But instead of an atmosphere of matter, it's an atmosphere of extreme gravity. For all we know, there could be simply nothing
between the core of a black hole and its event horizon. I believe that to be the case, though I have no real empirical basis
to support that claim. Instead, a black hole's mass is concentrated only right at its core. We call it a singularity, which I
know to be physics jargon for: I don't know what the fuck it is, but it's massive and unimaginably dense!
Now for this part I'd like to hear from quantum physisists and partical physisists. When neutrons are crushed beyond their limits,
what sort of matter do you get? Whatever it is, to me the only form of matter or anything else with mass that could exist in these
conditions, is just pure energy. Energy comes in all forms, shapes and magnitudes. It doesn't care a lick how it's constituted,
all it cares about is that it cannot be destroyed or created. Mass and matter is simply a concentration of pure energy,
as Einstein has proved. And it's this concentration that has the ability to distort space-time. That distortion is gravity.
Why should the singularity be any different? All it can be is energy in a form we just don't understand yet. It may not even
care about the concept of volume anymore either: for all we know, every black hole's core, no matter how massive, is of the same
volume. All the mass it eats simply gets transformed into the same form of energy it is made out of and just becomes a part of it.
A black hole's core could be equally probable to be the same size it started at the very moment it was born: no bigger, perhaps even
smaller than an atom, or grow as it eats.
Of course, I can equally support the idea that a black hole's core does grow in volume with an increase in mass. Information
must be stored somehow, perhaps on its surface. It's just that, those concepts we have of volume being needed to store information
might just not apply to a singularity. Physics as we know it doesn't work down here. When thinking of things existing in conditions
like these, I think it's best to assume nothing from the laws we have so far uncovered, only keeping them on the side as
guidelines instead.

3. Lastly, this is about what the consequences are of the black hole's existance in regards to space-time are.
The first question I think we need to answer here is: can space-time tear? We know it's malleable and that energy deforms it.
But if enough energy is concentrated in one place like with a black hole, would the singularity be able to tear through
space-time itself? If the answer is no, then all you will find down there is just the black hole's core.
If the answer is yes, then a black hole can serve as a portal through space-time. Where you will end up in, nobody knows,
I don't even have any speculation other than that it is either another place within the universe or another universe
altogether. What I do believe strongly is that regardless of either, managing the trip would mean travel through time and not just
space. There are just two issues with achieving this:
1: you'd need to be able to somehow retain the structure and constitution of your own information while traveling down the black hole,
I.E how not to get crushed to bits. You'd probably need an amount of energy greater than what the black hole is made of in order
to resist it.
2: How to navigate. Getting into contact with the black hole's core is probably a death sentence for all eternity. It would
also be the center of the portal, which is perhaps only microscopic anyway. One would need to devise a method by which they
could slip into the portal and not touch the singularity.

4. I hope this might have tickled some of those physics eggheads's brains. I'm just a writer with a high-school degree with a
minor interest in this sort of stuff. I do not have any real, empirical basis to support any of this. Really, it's just an opinion.
I'm just hoping that someone way smarter than me will actually be able to research these ideas. It's just my own way of attempting
to contribute. Hope you liked it, have a good day.

4. I hope this might have tickled some of those physics eggheads's brains. I'm just a writer with a high-school degree with a 
minor interest in this sort of stuff. I do not have any real, empirical basis to support any of this. Really, it's just an opinion.
I'm just hoping that someone way smarter than me will actually be able to research these ideas. It's just my own way of attempting
to contribute. Hope you liked it, have a good day.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've read and heard many physicists say that in a black hole, time from your perspective would slow down so much that you would watch the entire rest of life of the universe play out from inside. How would that be possible if the specific black hole you (hypothetically) find yourself in, dissipates before the end of the universe?
If information isn't lost inside, could you (theoretically) send something inside that could record the end of the universe, then retrieve the recorded information to "watch the playback" when the black hole dissipates?

snippet.textDisplay: How the hell can random quantum fluctuations produce black holes? Even if they could, wouldn't they be ultra tiny and sputter out of existence almost immediately, especially with no matter around to consume? Also, don't black holes eventually evaporate due to hawking radiation? What are the implications on this theory given that they do? Does that mean universes themselves evaporate, or is the body of the black hole that initiated the space-time expansion of its child universe not necessary for the perpetuation of its child universe?

snippet.textDisplay:
There are two things that really bother me about this idea.
The first was made in the video, how can we extrapolate our current models of physics to the extreme environments that we don’t have good explanations about how they behave.
The second is, how can we assume that something as cosmically insignificant as Earth’s process of natural selection applies to other universes? We don’t even know if the idea of random mutation interacting with another environment is even a valid proposition for another planet in our own stellar neighborhood, let alone across the galaxy, and it’s a bigger leap to assume this works in other galaxies.
As a side note, the idea that the fundamental constants act the same as genetic information is also a pretty extravagant claim.
Happy to read your reply.
